questions.question: I will wait here until you …………………..
questions.description: When both clauses refer to future, use a simple future in the main clause and simple present in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: If I knew that you were coming, I ……………………….. dinner.
questions.description: In the second conditional, use a simple past in the if-clause and would + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: If they had paid heed to the warning signs, this …………………………..
questions.description: In the third conditional, use a past perfect in the if-clause and would + have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: It took me quite sometime to get used to ………………………… in a large city.
questions.description: The to in used to is a preposition. A verb used after a preposition should be in its ing form.

questions.question: What she said ………………………. no sense to me.
He asked me if I ………………………. him some money.
questions.description: 'Can you lend me some money?' he asked. He asked if I could lend him some money. Can in direct speech becomes could in indirect speech.

questions.question: I waited and waited but he …………………… come.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the simple past, use a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: I …………………………. to anybody.
questions.description: The present perfect is used to refer to time up to now.

questions.question: I will give you a call when I …………………….. ready.
questions.description: When both clauses refer to future, use a simple future in the main clause and simple present in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: I asked him where he ……………………….. the previous day.
questions.description: I asked him, 'Where were you yesterday?' I asked him where he had been the previous day. Simple past in the direct speech becomes past perfect in the indirect speech.

questions.question: It is time you ……………………… a job.
questions.description: Use a simple past after it is time.

questions.question: I would rather you ………………………… home now.
questions.description: Use a simple past after would rather.
